TEXT.English: Wizard's Hall
TEXT.French: Wizard's Hall
TEXT.German: Wizard's Hall
TEXT.Italian: Wizard's Hall
TEXT.Spanish: Auditorio de Brujos

TEXT.English: While other empires' mages are cloistered up in guilds that have limited access to and from the outside world, Amurite wizards are more than welcome to share their knowledge with their fellow citizens. This change in view is due to both the actions of Kylorin and the example of Govannon. The Wizard's Hall is open to all Amurites, meaning any citizen of the empire could pick something up. It also serves the same purposes as a mage's guild - training adepts to go out into the world.
TEXT.French: While other empires' mages are cloistered up in guilds that have limited access to and from the outside world, Amurite wizards are more than welcome to share their knowledge with their fellow citizens. This change in view is due to both the actions of Kylorin and the example of Govannon. The Wizard's Hall is open to all Amurites, meaning any citizen of the empire could pick something up. It also serves the same purposes as a mage's guild - training adepts to go out into the world.
TEXT.German: While other empires' mages are cloistered up in guilds that have limited access to and from the outside world, Amurite wizards are more than welcome to share their knowledge with their fellow citizens. This change in view is due to both the actions of Kylorin and the example of Govannon. The Wizard's Hall is open to all Amurites, meaning any citizen of the empire could pick something up. It also serves the same purposes as a mage's guild - training adepts to go out into the world.
TEXT.Italian: While other empires' mages are cloistered up in guilds that have limited access to and from the outside world, Amurite wizards are more than welcome to share their knowledge with their fellow citizens. This change in view is due to both the actions of Kylorin and the example of Govannon. The Wizard's Hall is open to all Amurites, meaning any citizen of the empire could pick something up. It also serves the same purposes as a mage's guild - training adepts to go out into the world.
TEXT.Spanish: Mientras los magos de otros imperios están enclaustrado en grenios que tienen aceso mínimo al mundo exterior, magos Amuritos son recibido con mucho agrado en compartir su conocimiento con sus compatriotas. Este cambio es a cause de las acciones de Kylorin y también el ejemplo de Govannon. El Auditorio de Brujos está abierto a todos los Amuritos, así cualquiera compatriota del imperio puede aprender algo. También cumple el mismo utilidad de un gremio de magos - enseñar a los adeptos para ir al mundo.

TEXT.English: As the election grows near, disputes have broken out in the Senate. One group favours an aggressive foreign policy and suggests war against old rivals. The other advocates a more diplomatic approach and concentration of forces for defense only. Whichever side gains the most support will shape the senate for the coming term.
TEXT.French: As the election grows near, disputes have broken out in the Senate. One group favours an aggressive foreign policy and suggests war against old rivals. The other advocates a more diplomatic approach and concentration of forces for defense only. Whichever side gains the most support will shape the senate for the coming term.
TEXT.German: As the election grows near, disputes have broken out in the Senate. One group favours an aggressive foreign policy and suggests war against old rivals. The other advocates a more diplomatic approach and concentration of forces for defense only. Whichever side gains the most support will shape the senate for the coming term.
TEXT.Italian: As the election grows near, disputes have broken out in the Senate. One group favours an aggressive foreign policy and suggests war against old rivals. The other advocates a more diplomatic approach and concentration of forces for defense only. Whichever side gains the most support will shape the senate for the coming term.
TEXT.Spanish: Mientras la elección se acerca, disputas se han desatado en el Senado. Un grupo prefiere una policia exterior agresiva y sugiere guerra contra rivales viejos. El otro aboga de un enfoque más diplomático y concentración de fuerzas para defender solamente. Cualquier lado gana lo más soporte moldeará el Senado durante el mandato que viene.

TEXT.English: Some areas of the republic are close to revolt due to disputes between wealthy landowners and the poorer populace that live on their lands. The landowners seek more money from the peasants, but they can ill afford to pay. As the election approaches, this is sure to be a topic in the debates.
TEXT.French: Some areas of the republic are close to revolt due to disputes between wealthy landowners and the poorer populace that live on their lands. The landowners seek more money from the peasants, but they can ill afford to pay. As the election approaches, this is sure to be a topic in the debates.
TEXT.German: Some areas of the republic are close to revolt due to disputes between wealthy landowners and the poorer populace that live on their lands. The landowners seek more money from the peasants, but they can ill afford to pay. As the election approaches, this is sure to be a topic in the debates.
TEXT.Italian: Some areas of the republic are close to revolt due to disputes between wealthy landowners and the poorer populace that live on their lands. The landowners seek more money from the peasants, but they can ill afford to pay. As the election approaches, this is sure to be a topic in the debates.
TEXT.Spanish: Unas areas del repúblico están acercándose de una rebelión a causa de disputas entre terratenientes ricos y la población más pobre que viven en sus propiedades. Los terratenientes buscan más dinero de los campesinos, pero los campesinos no pueden pagar. Mientras se acerca la elección, seguramente esto será un tópico en los debates.

TEXT.English: Some members of the senate are suggesting that old laws stemming from religious tradition are hampering the ability of the government to provide for the people. Others argue that without the laws our nation would be without a moral compass and prone to fall prey to our baser desires. Both sides are lobbying for support in the coming election.
TEXT.French: Some members of the senate are suggesting that old laws stemming from religious tradition are hampering the ability of the government to provide for the people. Others argue that without the laws our nation would be without a moral compass and prone to fall prey to our baser desires. Both sides are lobbying for support in the coming election.
TEXT.German: Some members of the senate are suggesting that old laws stemming from religious tradition are hampering the ability of the government to provide for the people. Others argue that without the laws our nation would be without a moral compass and prone to fall prey to our baser desires. Both sides are lobbying for support in the coming election.
TEXT.Italian: Some members of the senate are suggesting that old laws stemming from religious tradition are hampering the ability of the government to provide for the people. Others argue that without the laws our nation would be without a moral compass and prone to fall prey to our baser desires. Both sides are lobbying for support in the coming election.
TEXT.Spanish: Unos miembros del Senado están sugeriendo que leyes viejos stemming from religious tradition are hampering the ability of the government to provide for the people. Others argue that without the laws our nation would be without a moral compass and prone to fall prey to our baser desires. Both sides are lobbying for support in the coming election.

TEXT.English: The senate is divided. Several popular senators have recently criticized the lack of education amongst the working class, leading to some heated rebuttals. Those senators supporting the interests of the workers argue that without the sweat and blood of those workers, the empire would be nothing. The two sides have become deadlocked whenever funds must be divided between the workers or the intellectuals. Hopefully the results of the election will free the senate to act.

Those senators supporting the interests of the workers argue that without the sweat and blood of those workers, the empire would be nothing. The two sides have become deadlocked whenever funds must be divided between the workers or the intellectuals. Hopefully the results of the election will free the senate to act.

TEXT.English: The election is fiercely contested, but your support was not enough. The opposition have a majority, which will make life more difficult for you this term.

TEXT.English: 'This is hardly the time for soft words, we must respond with action. If war is needed, then war we shall have!'
TEXT.French: 'This is hardly the time for soft words, we must respond with action. If war is needed, then war we shall have!'
TEXT.German: 'This is hardly the time for soft words, we must respond with action. If war is needed, then war we shall have!'
TEXT.Italian: 'This is hardly the time for soft words, we must respond with action. If war is needed, then war we shall have!'
TEXT.Spanish: 'This is hardly the time for soft words, we must respond with action. If war is needed, then war we shall have!'

TEXT.English: 'The world is violent enough - surely the solution cannot be more warfare. Give peace a chance.'
TEXT.French: 'The world is violent enough - surely the solution cannot be more warfare. Give peace a chance.'

TEXT.Italian: 'The world is violent enough - surely the solution cannot be more warfare. Give peace a chance.'
TEXT.Spanish: 'The world is violent enough - surely the solution cannot be more warfare. Give peace a chance.'

TEXT.English: 'Let the people decide what is worth fighting for.'
TEXT.French: 'Let the people decide what is worth fighting for.'
TEXT.German: 'Let the people decide what is worth fighting for.'
TEXT.Italian: 'Let the people decide what is worth fighting for.'
TEXT.Spanish: 'Let the people decide what is worth fighting for.'

TEXT.English: 'The landowners are the key to our economy and our wealth - why should we care about a few complaining peasants?'
TEXT.French: 'The landowners are the key to our economy and our wealth - why should we care about a few complaining peasants?'
TEXT.German: 'The landowners are the key to our economy and our wealth - why should we care about a few complaining peasants?'
TEXT.Italian: 'The landowners are the key to our economy and our wealth - why should we care about a few complaining peasants?'
TEXT.Spanish: 'The landowners are the key to our economy and our wealth - why should we care about a few complaining peasants?'

TEXT.English: 'The job of the senate is to serve the people. We must hear their grievances and act upon them.'

TEXT.German: 'The job of the senate is to serve the people. We must hear their grievances and act upon them.'
TEXT.Italian: 'The job of the senate is to serve the people. We must hear their grievances and act upon them.'
TEXT.Spanish: 'The job of the senate is to serve the people. We must hear their grievances and act upon them.'

TEXT.English: 'Let the votes reflect the will of the majority.'

TEXT.German: 'Let the votes reflect the will of the majority.'
TEXT.Italian: 'Let the votes reflect the will of the majority.'
TEXT.Spanish: 'Let the votes reflect the will of the majority.'

TEXT.English: 'These laws are the foundation of our civilization - how can we now turn our back on tradition?'
TEXT.French: 'These laws are the foundation of our civilization - how can we now turn our back on tradition?'
TEXT.German: 'These laws are the foundation of our civilization - how can we now turn our back on tradition?'
TEXT.Italian: 'These laws are the foundation of our civilization - how can we now turn our back on tradition?'
TEXT.Spanish: 'These laws are the foundation of our civilization - how can we now turn our back on tradition?'

TEXT.English: 'We are a civilized nation - removing these antiquated laws will not change that. Let our government progress with the times.'
TEXT.French: 'We are a civilized nation - removing these antiquated laws will not change that. Let our government progress with the times.'
TEXT.German: 'We are a civilized nation - removing these antiquated laws will not change that. Let our government progress with the times.'

TEXT.Spanish: 'We are a civilized nation - removing these antiquated laws will not change that. Let our government progress with the times.'

TEXT.English: 'The senate is able to decide for themselves which laws need to be repealed or upheld'

TEXT.German: 'The senate is able to decide for themselves which laws need to be repealed or upheld'
TEXT.Italian: 'The senate is able to decide for themselves which laws need to be repealed or upheld'
TEXT.Spanish: 'The senate is able to decide for themselves which laws need to be repealed or upheld'

TEXT.English: 'The workers are the bedrock of our civilization. Let no man residing in a high tower scorn them, for they built his high tower with their own hands.'
TEXT.French: 'The workers are the bedrock of our civilization. Let no man residing in a high tower scorn them, for they built his high tower with their own hands.'
TEXT.German: 'The workers are the bedrock of our civilization. Let no man residing in a high tower scorn them, for they built his high tower with their own hands.'

TEXT.Spanish: 'The workers are the bedrock of our civilization. Let no man residing in a high tower scorn them, for they built his high tower with their own hands.'

TEXT.English: 'The working man has not the knowledge to comprehend the nature of government with all of its complexity. The senate should be controlled by the wisest among us.'
TEXT.French: 'The working man has not the knowledge to comprehend the nature of government with all of its complexity. The senate should be controlled by the wisest among us.'
TEXT.German: 'The working man has not the knowledge to comprehend the nature of government with all of its complexity. The senate should be controlled by the wisest among us.'

TEXT.Spanish: 'The working man has not the knowledge to comprehend the nature of government with all of its complexity. The senate should be controlled by the wisest among us.'

TEXT.English: 'I hold both parties in equal esteem and we cannot do without either. I suggest you settle the dispute quickly.'

TEXT.English: Your people have always been spiritual, so it is not surprising that they have chosen to respect tradition. It is said however that even deaf ears were turned by the words of a single street preacher...

TEXT.Spanish: The workforce is key to the future of your civilization and thankfully the senate has realized it. [Gained the Industrious trait for this election term].

TEXT.English: It is only natural that the wisest minds lead the senate to the best decisions, in the interests of the people. Fortunately you have some of the wisest minds amongst your counsellors.

TEXT.English: The working class is concerned with things that are, but the senate should be concerned with things that could be. [Gained the Philosophical trait for this election term].

TEXT.English: Awaken Cold Iron
TEXT.French: Awaken Cold Iron
TEXT.German: Awaken Cold Iron
TEXT.Italian: Awaken Cold Iron
TEXT.Spanish: Despertar el Hierro Frío

TEXT.English: Today's battle with Fadious was epic; few could have survived the wounds inflicted on Lucian. But Lucian had to be strong or some upstart pup would challenge him. The march to Illian lands will be hard, and he would only have one night to lick his wounds. With camp set, Lucian retired to his bear pelt tent. The vomit could not be held back any longer and with a great purge every wound on his body opened filling the room with the stench of blood and bile. His strength gone and the world spinning, Lucian passed out. Dreams of victory, loss, blood, gore, riches all filled his head and a voice range out, "You will die tonight - your battles will be in vain." Lucian could not respond. "I can save you", the voice said, "but the price itself may get you killed". Lucian did not care; he was dying anyway. With one thought he agreed to the voice's unknown terms. "I am Cold Iron, forged by the god of winter, slayer of thousands. The weapon you have defiled with your blood and bile will bind your wounds and consume half of your soul." Lucian awakened bathed in his own juices, but there were no wounds; however, a deep weakness pulsed through him. He would have to be careful and hope a priest can restore some of his strength. Looking over at his axe, two points of blue light shown in the eye sockets of its skull, but no words would ever come forth from it again.

TEXT.Spanish: La batalla con Fadioso hoy fue épica; pocos pudiera sobrevivir las heridas infligidas a Lucian. Pero Lucian tenía que quedarse fuerte o algún avenedizo le lanzaría desafío. La marcha a la tierra de los Ilianos será difícil, y tendría solamente una noche para lamerse las heridas. Con la campa hecha, Lucian se retiró a su tienda de piel de oso. No podía contenir el vómito y con un gran purgo cada herida de su cuerpo se abrió, llenando el cuarto co el hediondez de sangre y bilis. Su fuerza perdido y el mundo dándole vueltas, Lucian se desmayó. Sueños de victorias, pérdidas, sangre, y riquezas llenaron su cabeza y una voz resonó, "Usted se morirá esta noche - sus batallas están en vanos." Lucian no podía responder. "Puedo salvarle," la voz dijo, "pero el precio puede matarle." A Lucian no importó; estaba muriendo en todo caso. Con un pensado estaba de acuerdo con los termos desconocidos de la voz. "Soy Hierro Frío, forjado por el dios del invierno, matador de miles. El arma que has manchado con su sangre y bilis vendará sus heridas y consumirá una mitad de su alma." Lucian se despertó bañado en sus propios jugos
